page.title: 18Red Hall Farm
page.content: This is a typical farm and has 13 fields covering 240 acres. It has been owned by the Pheysey family since 1912. My uncle Peter (the present owner) is interested in rare breeds of cattle and he keeps a mixture of Devon Reds, Old Gloucesters and Limousin together with modern Charolais, Herefords and Friesians. The cattle eat grass in the summer and silage in the winter. He also keeps 800 pigs which are reared and sold through a farming syndicate. They eat a mixture of soya bean, fish meal and corn. The crops produced are mainly wheat, grass for silage and hay and barley. Good barley is used to produce malt which is used to make beer, the rest is used for bread flour and the poorer quality for animal feed. My uncle uses a lot of modern machinery, but he shares the more expensive items. (Pamela Pheysey)
